did.abstract: Wesley H. Maurer, Sr., was a professor of journalism at the University of Michigan, and served as chair of the department from 1949 to 1966. He actively critiqued the journalism field, and was very involved in improving journalism education. Maurer was instrumental in establishing the internship program at the University of Michigan, and bought newspapers to provide students with work-experience, two of which he continued to operate until his death. Maurer was also involved in promoting democracy and free speech in the community.

bioghist.p: Wesley Henry Maurer, Sr. was born on January 19, 1897 in Bunker Hill, Illinois. He married Margaret E. Weber in 1944. They had three children: Margaret, Wesley H. Jr. , and Marilyn.

Maurer was educated at the University of Missouri, earning his A.B. degree in economics in 1921, his B.S. degree in Public and Business Administration in 1922, and his B.J. degree in journalism in 1923. He served as an editor on various papers before becoming an instructor at the University of Michigan from 1924 to 1925. He was an assistant professor of journalism at Ohio University from 1925 to 1928.

Maurer re-joined the University of Michigan faculty in 1928, as an instructor. He became an associate professor in 1932, and a professor in 1948. Maurer became chair of the journalism department in 1949 and served in that capacity until 1966, when he retired.

As a professor, Maurer emphasized the importance of practical experience. He was instrumental in improving the fellowship and internship programs of the Department of Journalism. He also established the Michigan Journalist, an experimental newspaper written by students that was circulated to publishers, editors, and teachers of journalism. Maurer bought several newspapers, including the Harbor Light, and the Mackinac Island Town Crier, which employed mostly students. Maurer also owned and operated the St. Ignace News and the Cedarville Weekly Wave (which later folded into the St. Ignace News).

While he was teaching at the University of Michigan, Maurer lead an adult education discussion group called "American Affairs and World Events." It met once a week in Detroit. During each session, the group discussed a controversial topic, based on the abstract of a book prepared by one of the members. Maurer began the class in 1929 and continued until 1967. At the time, it was the oldest discussion group of its kind in the country.

After his retirement, Maurer continued operating the St. Ignace weekly paper and the summer weekly paper the Town Crier on Mackinac Island, functioning as editor and publisher, until his death in 1995 at the age of 98.

scopecontent.p: The Maurer collection documents Wesley H. Maurer's career as a journalist and as a teacher of journalism. The collection has been arranged into the following series: Personal; Department of Journalism Administration; Michigan Federation of Teachers; Papers and Speeches; and Teaching.

scopecontent.p: Personal (0.5 linear feet) includes biographical information, awards, correspondence, and a few poems that Maurer wrote about journalism. The correspondence (1933-1992) often concerns issues in journalism.

scopecontent.p: Department of Journalism Administration (1 linear foot) covers materials pertaining to the functioning of the department. It includes department missions and goals, which are also emphasized in the department reviews of 1959 and 1963. There are also materials on the fellowship and internship programs that Maurer helped establish, and the newspapers which he ran and used to provide experience for students. Also included are materials on the seventy-fifth anniversary of the department, in 1966. The planning for the event, the speeches and discussions during the event, and Maurer's retirement celebration are documented. Also of note are materials pertaining to Maurer's defense of free speech during the 1940's and 1950's against concerns of Communism, including the controversy surrounding the dismissal of Professor H. Chandler Davis of the University of Michigan.

scopecontent.p: Michigan Federation of Teachers (0.25 linear feet) consists of papers pertaining to the University of Michigan and Ann Arbor chapter of the American Federation of Teachers, the teacher's union. Maurer was a charter member. The union was involved primarily with defending teachers from unlawful firing and support of the tenure act. Maurer was also involved in creating a film strip on the need for financial aid for higher education in 1940 that was widely circulated.

scopecontent.p: Papers and Speeches (1.5 linear feet) include articles Maurer wrote and notes for speeches he gave on a variety of topics. Articles often have edited drafts and correspondence reacting to them. Topics include Maurer's critique of the journalism profession, community activism and democracy, the state of the education system, community health issues, and the Church. The articles entitled "Maurer Philosophy" provide a synthesis of his beliefs about news and journalism, developed over the course of his career. The folders "Lectures #1-8" are Maurer's designation, and have an accompanying index of the papers in each folder. These papers cover many topics, with a focus on democracy and journalism education.

scopecontent.p: Teaching (1.5 linear feet) covers all of Maurer's teaching activities. The papers from the Department of Journalism classes include syllabi, and notes for lectures and class activities. There are also papers from his guest lectures series in Quito, Ecuador, in September 1964, at the Center for Advanced Study of Journalism for Latin American (CIESPAL). Of special significance are the papers regarding the American Affairs and World Events adult-education discussion group. Maurer created the group in 1929 and continued to lead it until 1967. Members of the class discussed current, controversial issues. The papers include lists of the books and topics discussed each year, as well as the group's newsletter and advertising for the class. Also of note is correspondence with former students, reflecting on their valuable experiences with him as a professor.
